story: NewsTories' 'secretly plotting to replace Theresa May with Michael Gove - before Ruth Davidson steps in'The plot has reportedly been dubbed the ‘Gove-Davidson succession’ and would see the Environment Secretary in no.10 for two years until the Scottish Conservatives chief takes over&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter00:05, 26 MAY 2018NewsSecretary of State for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs Michael Gove (Image: Wiktor Szymanowicz / Barcroft Media)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Tories are formulating a plan for Michael Gove to take Theresa May's role as Prime Minister - before paving the way for Ruth Davidson to serve in 2021, it is claimed. But Mr Gove would just be in no.10 for a transitional period until Scottish Conservatives chief Ms Davidson takes over, according to 'the plan'. Ms Davidson is often tipped as a future leader. title: budget brand beef burgers taste
story: NewsBudget brand beef burgers taste better than posh ones costing almost doubleThe expensive, premium burgers came last after judges branded them “a huge disappointment” and slammed the taste as “awful”&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByRuki SayidConsumer Editor00:01, 26 MAY 2018NewsThe 'gourmet' burgers did not live up to their name (Image: Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBudget brand beef burgers taste better than posh ones costing almost double, a consumer watchdog has revealed.  A panel of experts from Which? held blind taste tests on supermarket’s premium range burgers - and gave a pack of &pound2.49 burgers from discounter Aldi 75 out of 100 for hitting the taste spot while patties for &pound4.50 from restaurant chain Gourmet Burger Kitchen scored just 56.  The expensive, premium burgers came last after judges branded them “a huge disappointment” and slammed the taste as “awful” and the texture as “hideous”.  As the nation gears up for a BBQ bonanza this weekend, experts awarded Aldi’s Specially Selected Aberdeen Angus Beef Quarter Pounders (454g) a “great value” sticker.  UK weather: Bank holiday weekend to kick off with downpours before turning into 30C scorcher  The panel said they were “tasty with the right amount of seasoning”. A pack of two Irresistible Hereford Beef Burgers (340g) for &pound3.19 from the Co-op were crowned supermarket burger king with the top score of 82.  Judges said the patties were “perfect” and “the burgers to choose this summer” because they were juicy with a “great beefy taste”.  But at the other end of the scale, bespoke Hand Pressed Beef Burgers (340g) costing &pound3.74 from upmarket store Waitrose scored just 62 and were panned for lacking flavour and being “tough when cooked”.  Nine packs of beef burgers from supermarket chiller cabinets were judged on appearance, taste, texture, smell and tenderness in a blind tasting session.  Nikki Stopford, director of research and publishing at Which? said: “Barbecues are a staple of any British bank holiday weekend, so shoppers will be delighted to know they don’t have to pay over the odds for a great burger this summer. “Our taste test results found that price and brand are no indication of quality, meaning everyone can enjoy a great barbecue this weekend - weather permitting!” Judges’ verdicts - marks out of 100 Co-op Irresistible Hereford Beef Burgers (340g), &pound3.19 - 82 Aldi Specially Selected Aberdeen Angus Beef Quarter Pounders (454g), &pound2.49 - 75 Marks &amp Spencer Our Best Ever Burger (340g), &pound3.50 - 75 Morrisons The Best 60z Chuck Steak Burgers (340g), &pound3.50 - 74 Tesco Finest Beef Steak Burgers (454g), &pound3 - 74

story: NewsFirst-time mum given horror cancer diagnosis at 17-weeks pregnant now has happy and healthy two-year-old daughterSuzanne Roche, 34, from Dublin, was diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma less than half way through her pregnancy&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByEmma Costello19:01, 25 MAY 2018NewsSuzanne and her daughter, Zoe. (Image: internet unknown)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA first-time mum who underwent gruelling chemotherapy treatment for half of her pregnancy has told of her relief after giving birth to a healthy baby girl.  Suzanne Roche, from Dublin, received the shock diagnosis she had Hodgkin's lymphoma when she was just 17 weeks pregnant, the Irish Mirror reports .  Alarm bells were raised when doctors discovered a swollen lymph node in the 34-year-old's neck. She explained: “I was lucky the treatment didn’t hit me too hard - I didn’t lose my hair and I wasn’t very sick with it. “The worst was the fatigue - it was incredible fatigue - I was exhausted all the time.”  Going through chemotherapy while being pregnant is a concern for many women and while Suzanne was able to continue, she did have to take a break a month before her daughter Zoe was due.  She told RSVP Live : “I tried to keep things as ‘normal’ as possible, I kept working as much as I was able, taking time off each time I had chemo.  “By all accounts I had a standard pregnancy - I went to all the prenatal classes, took my prenatal vitamins, tried to keep up some sort of exercise. “My obstetrician kept a close eye on myself and the baby and I got regular scans. “I started chemotherapy treatment in my 20th week of the pregnancy and had eight sessions before we stopped around about a month before I was due to give my body a break and allow me to recover before childbirth. “I was lucky to have had a natural birth which went smoothly. About three weeks after Zoe was born I went back to finish my chemotherapy, completing my treatment in November 2016.” “About three weeks after Zoe was born I went back to finish my chemotherapy, completing my treatment in November 2016.”

title: four year old boy starved
story: NewsFour-year-old boy starved to death while clinging to mum’s undiscovered body after she suffered fatal epileptic fitChadrack Mbala Mulo died two weeks after his mum suffered a fatal epileptic fit at home in Hackney, East London - and his tragic death has sparked a new rule in all UK schools&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDave Burke17:59, 25 MAY 2018Updated19:26, 25 MAY 2018NewsChadrack Mbala-Mulo was found clinging to his mum's dead body at their home in East London (Image: Facebook)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA schoolboy who starved to death when his mum died at their home has prompted a new rule - which means schools should have two adult contacts for each child. Tragic Chadrack Mbala Mulo was just four when he died holding onto his mother's corpse in Hackney, East London, in October 2016. An inquest into his death heard that Chadrack, who was mute and autistic, had been absent from school for nearly three weeks when he was eventually discovered. When his mum, Esther Eketi-Mulo, died after suffering an epileptic fit, he was unable to fend for himself. Although staff had a contact number for his mum, they did not have any way of contacting other relatives.  Coroner Mary Hassell said that unless new rules were brought in, other children could die in a similar manner,  reported last year .   New rules introduced by the Department for Education say that schools and colleges must now have one emergency contact number per pupil, where reasonably possible.  Nadhim Zahawi, Minister for Children and Families, said:  “This was a truly tragic case. Schools and colleges play an important part in keeping children safe which is why have recently taken action to update guidance that all schools have on how to deal with concerns about a child.  This now includes a specific reference to ask that schools, where possible, hold more than one emergency contact number for each pupil.” It is thought Esther died on October 1 or 2, 2016, but she and her son were not found until October 20.  By that time Chadrack had been dead for around two days, as a result of dehydration and malnutrition. Neighbours at the Trelawney Estate in Hackney reportedly thought the stench coming from the family's flat was from the mum's cooking. Staff from his school, Morningside Primary, had visited the home twice and rang several times in early October but could not get in. Ms Hassell said: They ... could not gain access to the block of flats where Chadrack and his mother lived.

story: News'I can't see how it affects his education': Mum's anger over schoolboy, 14, sent home over 'army-style' haircutCharlotte Healy said her son Casey Healy was upset when St Thomas More Language College staff sent him home&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByKaty Clifton21:02, 25 MAY 2018NewsSt Thomas More Language College has stood by its strict behaviour guidelines (Image: Google Street View)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe mum of a 14-year-old schoolboy sent home over his 'army-style' haircut is now threatening to withdraw her son from school. Teachers ruled Casey Healy's recent trim - which he got specially for his brother's communion - was against the Chelsea school's policy. The prestigious college requires boys' hair be neat, tidy and a uniform length all over - with Casey's undercut allegedly failing to adhere to the rule.  His mother, Charlotte Healy, said her son has been left upset and worried after being sent home from school because of his hair shortly after registration at around 9.10am on Tuesday, getwestlondon reports .  The mum-of-three said: “They said that it's against their school uniform policy.  “It wasn't a dramatic cut, it was just a little bit shaved and then longer on the top. But he was sent home because I've already told them he isn't allowed to go into isolation. “He's come home scared and a bit worried over just a haircut. He has been [at the school] for three years, he has 100% attendance and his punctuality is 100%. “Casey hasn't gone back in today, so now he's missing more time off school, which he doesn't really need to be doing. He's got his GCSEs coming up. “I can't see how a haircut would affect his education. It wasn't dyed, it didn't have any lines or any patterns. I could understand if he had it spray painted or it was very extreme.”  The incident occurred at St Thomas More Language College on Tuesday. According to Miss Healy, 29, her son had his hair cut for his brother's communion on Sunday, which she explained to staff at St Thomas More school on Tuesday. She suggested the family would be “back in this predicament” in two weeks time because Casey has his confirmation, for which he needs to be neat and tidy for church. “I'm considering moving him from the school, which obviously I don't want to. I don't really feel comfortable sending him back,” Miss Healy added. “To get into this school we've had to go to church, we've had to make sure that we are there every Sunday. He's had to become an altar boy and his attendance is 100%, he is clean and tidy. “It is just a simple shave with a bit cut on the side. One of my neighbours even said that 'that's a lovely army haircut he has.'”

story: NewsMeghan Markle’s selling power could outshine even Kate Middleton's appealThe Duchess of Cambridge’s ability to sell out everything from a £175 Reiss dresses to those trademark pairs of nude LK Bennett pumps has caused a frenzy in the UK fashion industry&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByLaura Connor00:13, 26 MAY 2018Updated00:17, 26 MAY 2018NewsCould the Markle Sparkle could take over the Kate effect...?&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen Kate Middleton burst onto the scene with the announcement of her engagement to Prince William in 2010, the ‘Kate effect’ came into full-force. The Duchess of Cambridge’s ability to sell out everything from a &pound175 Reiss dresses to those trademark pairs of nude LK Bennett pumps has caused a frenzy in the UK fashion industry. But now she has a rival in the new Duchess of Sussex, as experts predict Meghan Markle’s selling power could outshine even Kate’s appeal. And it’s not just Meghan’s fashion which could give the UK economy a boost – the American former actress has the added bonus of pulling in sales from her homeland across the Atlantic. So could the Markle Sparkle could take over the Kate effect...? KATE  FASHION It’s estimated that Kate pumps &pound150million in revenue to the UK fashion industry every year, and her ability to sell out clothes is renowned. When her Sarah Burton wedding dress went on display at Buckingham Palace in the summer of 2011, approximately &pound8m was raised for the Royal Collection.  Meanwhile, a &pound38 Topshop dress she wore while pregnant with Prince George sold out within an hour of her wearing it to film studios.  And it’s not just luxury fashion and high street brands Kate helps promote. A &pound10 bracelet in aid of Suffolk’s Treehouse Hospice sold out after the Duchess of Cambridge was seen wearing one in 2012. BEAUTY Ever since it was reported that Trilogy Rosehip Oil is responsible for Kate’s glowing complexion, a bottle of the &pound16.50 product started selling every 20 seconds.  But her bouncy, blow-dried brunette locks are the real source of her beauty branding power. When it was revealed that the Duchess is a fan of Richard Ward Cleanse and Condition Shampoo, the &pound5.99 product sold out immediately in Waitrose.  Richard Ward is Kate’s hairdresser and &pound325 appointments at his Knightsbridge salon have seen waiting lists extend to six months since she became royalty. LIFESTYLE Kate and Prince William’s beloved dog Lupo is a treasured addition to their family, and is regularly seen in official portraits. The Kennel Club attributed the raised profile and interest in English Cocker Spaniels to Lupo, following a 50% surge in searches for the breed on their website following their ownership of the dog.  Meanwhile, the royal couple love taking the kids to the French Alps and after they were pictured visiting luxury skiing resort Courchevel, bookings for the three nearest airports spiked with 57% more flights booked than over the same dates the previous year. KIDS Valuation firm Brand Finance estimates that Princess Charlotte adds &pound101m to the UK economy each year, while her older brother Prince George adds &pound76m. At just six months old, Charlotte proved she had the same selling power as her mother. The &pound21 floral dress she wore a family portrait immediately sold out and its Spanish designer M&ampH was inundated with orders from around the world.  Meanwhile, Prince George’s cuddly kangaroo backpack sold-out just hours after Prince William was spotted holding it during a trip to Sydney in 2014.  FASHION In the run up to the Royal Wedding, Meghan caused several independent Canadian websites to crash by wearing their brands, including Line The Label, which she wore for her official engagement photos. She caused a 400% increase in traffic to jewellery site Birks, and a 1000% increase in sales to sunglasses brand Finlay &amp Co, just by wearing their products.  Since the Windsor ceremony on Saturday, there has been a 160% increase in searches for Stella McCartney wedding dresses – Meghan’s choice of designer for her evening gown. Richard Haigh, of Brand Finance, says the 36-year-old’s branding power will only continue to soar. “Following the wedding, we estimated that her brand power will be &pound150m a year, which is the same as Kate’s,” says Richard. “Based on our estimate, she could pull in the same kind of brand potential as Kate for the fashion industry.”  Meghan’s appeal could surpass Kate’s at the beginning, as she boosts American as well as UK brands, Professor Jonathan Shalit, who runs InterTalent, says. “The Meghan journey has been a completely phenomenal, unique journey,” he says. “The power of Meghan is quite staggering. I think she could be the biggest fashion brand in the world.” But Jonathan says there may be a shift over time. “I think right now she is the new kid on the block, and Kate is a mother-of-three,” he explains. “But eventually when Meghan has been doing this for a few years, they will both even out.” BEAUTY Down-to-earth Meghan was praised for the natural make-up and “messy bun” she sported on her wedding day, with hundreds of websites rushing to advise others on how to copy her style.  Online beauty brand Memi announced a 65% rise in sales of nude lipsticks since Meghan wore a taupe hue during her engagement interview. She also loves &pound7 Nivea’s Skin Firming Hydration Body Lotion to keep her skin moisturised. LIFESTYLE It’s no secret that the Duchess of Sussex loves keeping fit and healthy, reportedly converting Prince Harry to green juices and helping him quit smoking. She’s been pictured in a variety of yoga poses on her now defunct Instagram and loves running around Kensington Palace Green.  Since she was snapped in Kensington’s posh health shop Whole Foods, sales at organic independents and retailers have enjoyed a 9.7% sales jump to &pound359m.  Meghan’s also partial to a glass of wine, noting that her favourite red is the full-bodied and firm Tignanello – which she even named her lifestyle blog ‘The Tig’ after. While the yoga and pilates business brings in &pound812m into the UK economy a year, the new Duchess’s lifestyle choices could see an even greater spike in its popularity. title: obese people should allowed turn
story: NewsObese people should be allowed to turn up for work an hour later, government adviser recommendsThe plan could see obese office workers miss the rush hour commute, demand an extra large chair or even work from home&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science Correspondent23:00, 25 MAY 2018NewsNew research shows Brits are among most fat-ist in Europe (Image: Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFat workers should be allowed to turn up late and be protected under discrimination law, a leading employment specialist has said. The plan could see obese office workers miss the rush hour commute, demand an extra large chair or even work from home. A UK government advisor will propose changes at the European Congress on Obesity in Vienna as new research shows Brits are among most fat-ist in Europe. Prof Stephen Bevan has advised the Department of Work and Pensions and is a member of Public Health England’s advisory board. He will tell 2,000 medics that obesity should be classed as a “protected characteristic” allowing staff to sue fat shaming bosses.  Prof Bevan, head of HR research at the Institute for Employment Studies, said: “We need to coordinate our efforts so that people who want to work can do so. “It can be working time, it can be having a bit of understanding that someone might need to turn up at 10am because they have trouble with transport or anxiety about transport. “Many employers get away with whatever they want.” Prof Bevan will present a systematic review of research in to obesity workplace discrimination.  It included a major study on “weight stigma” in the NHS .  Another study found one in five Brits said they would object to an obese person marrying in to their family.  A third study by the European Association for the Study of Obesity found more than half of UK doctors thought overweight patients lacked willpower.  One in three said they were too lazy to keep weight off.  Prof Bevan added: “Some people say that obesity is the last characteristic that its still socially acceptable to make fun of .  “We have a scheme in the UK called Access to Work which not many employers know about. “If you are an individual living with a health condition or an impairment you can get support, paid for by the Government to make accommodations. “It could be transport or it could be working from home.”  Another study surveyed 90,573 people in nine countries and found only 47% of Brits believe food addiction is a reasonable explanation. This was lowest other than the US and Germany.

title: revealed shed world cup trophy
story: NewsRevealed: The shed where the World Cup trophy was hidden after being stolen while every policeman in Britain looked for itIt is thought to have still had the dust on it when Bobby Moore held it aloft&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByTom PettiforLouie Smith21:00, 25 MAY 2018Updated23:17, 25 MAY 2018News (Image: Phil Harris/Daily Mirror)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe stolen World Cup was hidden in a dingy coal shed and is thought to have still had the dust on it when Bobby Moore held it aloft. Sidney and Reginald Cugullere left London with the Jules Rimet trophy following their audacious raid.  With every policeman in Britain on the lookout for the cup, the brothers hid it in a brick lean-to outside Reg’s father-in-law’s home. The shed, at 71 Cowper Street, Luton, has survived the last half century but is currently in a state of disrepair.  Its wooden door is etched with graffiti and it is currently being used to house a washing machine.  'I'm in the dark about villains': Owner of Pickles the dog has never heard of 1966 World Cup heist thief  Reg's son Gary said: “My dad and uncle panicked and hid the World Cup in my grandfather’s coal shed. My mum told me he didn’t know anything about it. They just sneaked the trophy in and left it there until they had figured out what to do with it.”   Seven days after the World Cup was stolen it was found in a hedge by Pickles the dog and owner David Corbett.  Months later the trophy was raised by Bobby Moore at Wembley after England defeated West Germany 4-2.  Gary says his dad Reg, who died in 2012, believed traces of coal would have been on the cup when it was held aloft. He said: If the police carried out a forensic examination they would have found coal dust. A Mirror investigation revealed how Sid nicked the trophy from a glass display cabinet at the Methodist Central Hall in Westminster.  His brother Reg then put the cup under the front seat of his car and drove North to Bedfordshire The Cugulleres then stashed the priceless trophy while they worked out how to return it to the FA.  Historic records show Reg's wife Betty was living at 71 Cowper Street when she married in 1945, and her mum Nora died there in 1962.  Council documents prove Betty's dad Norman 'Jack' White, who worked as a lorry driver, was still living at the same address in 1966. Both Sid and Reg confided in Gary that the coal shed was where they hid the trophy for several days. The dilapidated outbuilding is now used as a makeshift washing room.

title: search audi a3 driver who
story: NewsSearch for Audi A3 driver who sped off after deadly fireball horror smashOfficers are hunting the driver of the grey Audi A3, which sped off after the horror smash in Edinburgh that left one person dead.&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJane HamiltonJames Moncur00:58, 26 MAY 2018NewsRemains of a burnt car on Maybury Road west of Edinburgh city centre (Image: SWNS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA fatal fireball crash was caused by a driver in a stolen vehicle, police believe. Officers are hunting the driver of the grey Audi A3, which sped off after the horror smash in Edinburgh that left one person dead. The car, which had false number-plates and may have been used in other crimes in the city, was found abandoned in Fife a few hours later. The crash happened close to Maybury roundabout in Edinburgh at about 12.30am yesterday. Witnesses told how the Audi drove over chevron road markings to overtake a number of vehicles, including a bus. It headed on to the oncoming carriageway, causing a BMW to swerve and hit a Peugeot 206, which was travelling in the opposite direction. Emergency services, including 14 firefighters, scrambled to the scene. It is understood fire crews initially believed every driver and passenger had been accounted for – but a victim was later discovered in the wreckage of the Peugeot, which had burst into flames. The BMW’s occupants – a 25-year-old man, 22-year-old woman and five-year-old girl – were all taken to hospital, where they continued to be treated for their injuries last night. The Audi was recovered in Lochgelly Road, Cowdenbeath – near to the local ambulance depot – at about 3.50am. It had been stolen from the Liberton area of Edinburgh on April 17.

title: she fought hard first baby
story: News"She has fought so hard": First baby born in UK with heart OUTSIDE body edges closer to going homeWARNING - GRAPHIC IMAGES: Miracle baby Vanellope Hope Wilkins has beaten EIGHT MILLION-to-one odds to survive the rare condition - and at six months old is closer to going home for first time&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByArun Lal22:58, 25 MAY 2018Updated22:59, 25 MAY 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe first baby in Britain to survive being born with her heart OUTSIDE her body is one step closer to going home. Six-month-old Vanellope Hope Wilkins has beaten eight-million-to-one odds to survive the ultra-rare condition. The battling tot has since made incredible progress, thanks to a specially designed jacket she was given to wear which acts as an external rib-cage and protects her heart. Her parents had been told there was next to no hope that she'd live when the abnormality was picked up at a nine-week scan. Mum Naomi Findlay, 31, and dad Dean Wilkins, 43, were advised to terminate the pregnancy but she refused and never gave up hope.  Vanellope's breast bone had failed to develop normally, causing her heart and part of her stomach to grow on the outside. The condition - called ectopia cordis - is extremely rare and most babies affected have a less than 10 per cent chance of survival. There were only a handful of cases worldwide where a baby has survived the condition and none in Britain. A team of 50 staff were on hand to assist when Vanellope was born by c-section at Glenfield Hospital in Leicester weighing 4lb 7oz at 9.50am on November 22 last year.  Six months on, she is still making an incredible recovery and has now been moved nearer to her family's home in Bullwell, Notts. She was transported from Leicester Royal Infirmary to Nottingham's Queen’s Medical Centre in Nottingham on Thursday. Her day-to-day care will today move to the medical team at Nottingham University Hospitals who will prepare her for going home in the coming weeks. Naomi spoke of her excitement and said she is looking forward to finally getting her baby home.  She added: “I started this journey, what seems like a long time ago now, when I had a scan at nine weeks pregnant. “There have been times when I really didn’t think she would make it, but she has fought so hard. I have been so incredibly lucky to have been surrounded by an amazing medical team. “It has been very hard for me and my other children over the last six months. “I have felt torn between my children, guilty when I am at home with my boys and then guilty when I’m in hospital with Vanellope, so this will be a huge relief and we will start to feel like a real family.

title: take home you scruffy fers
story: News"Take it home you scruffy f***ers!": Passer-by forces fly tippers to pick rubbish back upThe couple were spotted getting rid of bricks and stones by the side of a road - claiming their local tip was closed - but made to load it back in their car in Wakefield, West Yorkshire&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDave Burke19:58, 25 MAY 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the moment a passer-by caught a pair of fly tippers red-handed dumping rubbish in a field - and made them load it back in their car. The man and woman were spotted getting rid of bricks and stones by the side of a road. But passer-by - a builder - was having none of it, and filmed what happened on his mobile phone. The video footage of their exchange shows him telling them: Put it back in your car and take it home, you scruffy f***ers! He refused to leave until every last bit of debris was put back into the car. The builder, who asked not to be named, said: I just happened to be in the right place at the right time.  It's disgusting that people think they can go dumping their rubbish on other people's land - how would they like it in their back garden? There's absolutely no excuse for it and I wasn't going to let them get away with it. I had to put a stop to it. The clip shows him pulling up and confronting the pair dumping rubbish on a farmer's field near Wakefield, West Yorkshire. The builder can be heard asking what are you doing? before the couple seem to try and justify leaving the waste at the side of the road. But he refuses to let the matter, and shouts: Pick it all up and put it back in your car and take it home.  Go on hurry up. You don't throw it in someone else's field do you? How would you like it if I thew a load of s*** in your garden? He asks the couple why they don't take the waste to the tip and when they claim it's closed, he says: Go tomorrow then! On a number of occasions, the couple can be seen on video trying to apologise for their actions but the builder has no sympathy for them and forces them to carry on picking up their waste. After loading dozens of bricks back into their vehicle, he insists they also move some building rubble dumped at the side of the road. The pair claim the waste isn't theirs - until the man gets out of his work van and points out it must be as it's bone dry when it's pouring down with rain.  Take it to the tip like everyone else, or buy a skip, the builder says. He continues filming the pair as the woman puts on a pair of gloves and fills a black bin bag with rubble, which they load back into their dark blue people carrier. Before they drive away, the couple ask the builder to delete the recording of them fly tipping but he refuses, saying you've just been flytipping, I'm going to wait here until you've gone. Speaking afterwards, the builder who works from a site nearby, said: It's just not acceptable. I know there was a bit of f-ing and blinding from me but that's not a crime. They were fly tipping which is illegal. People are always leaving stuff there - sofas, chairs, building stuff, you name it - but I don't know what right they think they have.  I don't understand why they don't just take it to a tip, it doesn't cost them anything. I have a works vehicle so I can't do that and have to pay &pound200 to hire a skip, they're just being lazy. The builder said there is a refuse tip just ten minutes from the layby where he caught the fly tippers - and claims he followed the couple along a road just a mile or so from it after the incident. He has had a largely positive response form the video, which he says he took to encourage others to step in and stop others fly tipping. I want people to know they're within their rights to hold people to account. It's not OK for people to fly tip.

title: uk weather met office issues
story: NewsUK weather: Met Office issues 'yellow warning' of rain, hail and THUNDERSTORMS in blow to Bank Holiday heatwave hopesForecasters have warned there is a small chance that homes and businesses could be flooded - with damage to some buildings also predicted by lightning strikes, hail or strong winds&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter22:03, 25 MAY 2018Updated22:05, 25 MAY 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain will be battered by rain, hail and thunderstorms in a blow to high hopes of a bank holiday heatwave. The Met Office has issued a yellow warning for southern England for today, tomorrow and Sunday and say heavy showers will hit. Forecasters have warned there is a small chance that homes and businesses could be flooded, with damage to some buildings from floodwater, lightning strikes, hail or strong winds this weekend. The thundery showers in places will be mixed with warm sunny spells. Tonight there will be rain across some central parts becoming more sporadic overnight, still with some heavy bursts at times, the Met Office forecasts. Clear spells and patchy fog will be seen elsewhere, but further showers will hit southern England by dawn, perhaps turning heavy and thundery. Saturday is set for scattered downpours with hail pushing into the south, with warm sunshine in between.  Many northern areas will be fine and very warm, after early rain clears Northern England, the Met Office added. Forecasters are warning that, once the rain clears, it could be the hottest early May Bank Holiday weekend ever with temperatures hitting 30C. It will be warmest in the South East but the rest of the UK will experience glorious sunshine as well. The previous record set in late May was 32.8C, which was recorded in Horsham in 1944 on a Monday.  Martin Young, Deputy Chief Meteorologist at the Met Office, said: “There is a 50/50 chance we may see the warmest day of the year so far at some point towards the end of the weekend.” If the temperatures do break 30C it will also make it the warmest day of the year, beating with 29.1C taken on April 19 in St. James Park, London. But before it heats up motorists looking to get away today are at risk of heavy rain and thunderstorms. Saturday will be sunny for most, but with the risk of sharp showers for central and southern areas. The heaviest and most widespread showers are expected over south-west England, especially in the afternoon.  Sunday will be sunny for many northern and eastern parts, although there will be thundery showers again for central and southern portions of Britain. Met Office Chief Meteorologist Andy Page added: “There is a risk of potentially severe thunderstorms during the Bank Holiday weekend. Saturday: Rain in northern England will ease to leave many fine and very warm. Southern and southwestern areas will see further thundery showers, whilst coasts in northeast Scotland could remain misty. Outlook for Sunday to Tuesday: Very warm over the Bank Holiday weekend with plenty of sunshine, especially in the northwest. Scattered thunderstorms in the south, especially on Sunday. Mist returning to eastern coasts from Monday.

title: why me need help stop
story: News'Why me? I need help to stop them': Chilling final note written by French nanny found AFTER she was murdered by coupleSophie Lionnet, 21, was locked in a darkened room, starved, beaten, whipped with a cable and left with a broken chestbone and ribs&nbspShareByJoshua TaylorAssistant news editor17:17, 25 MAY 2018Updated18:09, 25 MAY 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA French nanny who was tortured and killed by a couple following sadistic 'interrogation' sessions left a chilling final note. Sophie Lionnet, 21, was starved, beaten, whipped with a cable and left with a broken chestbone ribs before being drowned in a bath. Her killers Sabrina Kouider, 35, and partner Ouissem Medouni, 40, were yesterday found guilty of murder. Police found a note written by a starving Sophie in the tiny, dark room where she was forced to sleep. It read simply: Why me? I need help to stop them. The victim's dad Patrick Lionnet, 56, told The Times: I will never hear her say 'daddy, I'm getting married' or 'daddy, I'm going to have a baby'.  Those people are not human, they are barbaric. They have no humanity in them at all. And her mum Catherine Devallonne, 49, said: They took away her dignity and finally her life painfully ebbed away, until Sophie struggled to take her last breath in that bath. Kouider and Medouni had a twisted obsession with Boyzone founder Mark Walton, Kouider's ex, and wrongly accused Miss Lionnet of conspiring with him. Her burnt body was eventually found on the couple's patio when firefighters were called to reports of foul-smelling smoke. In chilling audio recordings, captured on Kouider's phone, they could be heard firing questions at their terrified victim during the interrogation sessions, which took place over 12 days before her murder.  The violent questioning was conducted by the duo in a bid to force the nanny to confess to various false crimes. In the weeks leading up to her death in September last year, the couple beat, starved and tortured the shy 21-year-old by dunking her head into water. Having killed her in the bath, the pair threw her on a bonfire in the garden of their home near Wimbledon, south-west London, as they barbecued chicken nearby. The body was discovered when firefighters were alerted by neighbours to pungent-smelling smoke, but Medouni tried to pass off the charred remains as a sheep. And Kouider claimed to police that Miss Lionnet had run off with ex-byofriend Mr Walton in an attempt to frame him for her disappearance.  The defendants later admitted disposing of her body but denied Miss Lionnet's murder, blaming each other for her death. An Old Bailey jury found both of them guilty of the murder following a two-month trial that was described as stranger than fiction. Miss Lionnet's parents travelled from France to see the disturbing evidence as it unfolded. The court heard how fashion designer Kouider was fixated with her ex-boyfriend Mr Walton. After splitting up after two years, Kouider reported him to police more than 30 times and received a caution for branding him a paedophile on a fake Facebook profile.  She also accused him of sexually abusing a cat, using black magic and hiring a helicopter to spy on her. Giving evidence, LA-based Mr Walton said he had been in love with Kouider but she would flip and go crazy for no reason. Another ex-boyfriend Anthony Francois described her as a lunatic, fickle and unstable. Jurors heard more than eight hours of recordings in which Miss Lionnet was slapped, likened to a Nazi collaborator and called worse than a murderer by her tormentors. Kouider, who claimed to know influential people including US President Donald Trump, threatened to have her locked up and even marched her to a police station.  The victim's distraught mother had begged Kouider to send her daughter home but she refused. In her final days, Miss Lionnet was hit with an electrical cable and beaten so badly she had five broken ribs and a cracked breast bone. In a filmed forced confession, the emaciated and broken young woman claimed she had drugged Medouni so Mr Walton could sexually assault him. Within hours, she was dead. Before the trial, Medouni claimed Miss Lionnet died by accident after he punched her during an interrogation in the bath. He offered to admit manslaughter but later retracted his confession, saying he made it to protect his wife, who has been diagnosed with a borderline personality disorder.

title: experts baffled mysterious wolf like
story: NewsExperts baffled by mysterious wolf-like creature that has been called everything from a werewolf to BigfootAfter inspecting the creature experts said they doubt it's a wolf as its teeth were too short, front paws abnormally small and claws too large&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByRachel Bishop10:12, 26 MAY 2018NewsBizarre theories have circulated online that the animal could be a werewolf, a young grizzly bear or even a relative of Bigfoot (Image: Montana Fish WIldlife and Parks)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWildlife experts have been left baffled by a wolf-like creature that was shot dead by a farmer. Bizarre theories have circulated online that it could be a werewolf, a young grizzly bear or even a relative of Bigfoot. After inspecting the creature wolf experts have said they doubt it's a wolf as its teeth are too short, front paws abnormally small and claws too large. The animal came to the Department of Fish, Wildlife, and Parks attention last week after a rancher shot it dead when it came within several hundred metres of his livestock in Denton, Montana.   FWP spokesman Bruce Auchly said it was a young, non-lactating female and a canid, a member of the dog family that includes dogs , foxes, coyotes and wolves.  He added: We have no idea what this was until we get a DNA report back. Theories over what the animal could be have ranged from a coywolf - a coyote wolf hybrid- or perhaps a wolfdog bred in captivity and later released into the wild. Other suggested it could be a legendary Chupacabra but it is too far north for that.  One thing is for sure though - experts are not accepting as a wolf just yet - and DNA test results are not expected back for weeks.  Ty Smucker, wolf management specialist for Montana FWP, told the Great Falls Tribune : Several things grabbed my attention when I saw the pictures,  The ears are too big. The legs look a little short. The feet look a little small, and the coat looks weird. There's just something off about it.

title: north koreas infamous 105 storey
story: NewsNorth Korea's infamous 105-storey 'Hotel of Doom' is nearing completion after lying abandoned for decadesThe neglected building has been abandoned for years, but these images show it may be a going concern again&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMichael Havis22:35, 25 MAY 2018NewsThe hotel was supposed to have opened nearly 30 years ago (Image: MUST CREDIT: Pen News/Philippe Daniel)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNorth Korea's infamous 'Hotel of Doom' may finally be set to open - more than 25 years after it was supposed to welcome its first guests. The neglected building has been abandoned for years, but new pictures have emerged which show how it may be a going concern again. Stunning snaps show a column of lights scaling the full height of the notorious Ryugyong Hotel, culminating in an enormous LED display of the North Korean flag. The development comes as Kim Jong-un's secretive state attempts to build a world level beach resort in the coastal city of Wonsan in a bid to attract more tourists. Construction of the sinister-looking hotel began way back in 1987, and was supposed to open in 1989.  Had it finished on time, it would have been the tallest hotel in the world. Construction then stopped in 1992 as North Korea entered a period of economic crisis following the collapse of the Soviet Union. Photographer Philippe Daniel snapped the lights at the 105-storey skyscraper during a visit last month and was told they had been added only two weeks earlier. He said: There are two vertical lines of lights at the front of the hotel, those lights are moving upwards from the bottom to the top, colours shifting between blue and red. The tip of the hotel has a 360-degree LED panel showing an animated North Korean flag waving.   These aren't the highest resolution panels they could have used - you can still clearly see the pixels - but they're still impressive, especially when seen from the front with the vertical lights.  In the day, it doesn't look like there are any LED panels up there...  It must be individual LEDs embedded in the facade. French-born Mr Daniel, who now lives in Singapore, said his North Korean chaperons weren't keen to discuss the building, but there was no escaping it. It seemed like the guides didn't wanted to talk much about it, the 29-year-old said. But you can see it from everywhere. It's kind of the first thing you can see of Pyongyang, even from afar. I think it became more like a piece of the propaganda rather than a functional hotel.

story: NewsRyanair flight from Manchester to Tenerife 'speeds up' to destination after 'drunken row breaks out between passengers' arrested after landingAir traffic controllers revealed they had shortened the route of Flight FR4332/RYR23AY - and said "difficult passengers" were detained by police when the plane touched down&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByRita Sobot19:11, 25 MAY 2018Updated20:24, 25 MAY 2018NewsRyanair has called for a two-drink limit for passengers before they board flights (file photo) (Image: Reuters)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA bust-up on board a Ryanair flight from Manchester to Tenerife prompted pilots to speed up - and led to passengers being arrested after touch down.
